facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 820 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 820 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from the order dated July 4, 1961 of the Assam High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the order dated July 4, 1961 of the Assam High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1961.

facts.text: Shri Kishanlal Agarwalla died intestate in December 1950, leaving his widow and two minors, Basanta and Ashok.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Kishanlal Agarwalla died intestate in December 1950, leaving his widow and two minors, Basanta and Ashok.

facts.text: Prior to his death he was being assessed as an individual on the income arising from the business carried on in the name of Shri Krishan Rice Mills, Tezpur.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to his death he was being assessed as an individual on the income arising from the business carried on in the name of Shri Krishan Rice Mills, Tezpur.

facts.text: He was governed by Mitakshra School of Hindu Law.

anchor.surface_text: He was governed by Mitakshra School of Hindu Law.

facts.text: The widow also died in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The widow also died in 1952.

facts.text: On the death of the widow an application was made by Shri Nandlal Agarwalla to the Court of the District Judge, Gauhati, for being appointed as a guardian of the person and the properties of the two minors, Basanta and Ashok.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of the widow an application was made by Shri Nandlal Agarwalla to the Court of the District Judge, Gauhati, for being appointed as a guardian of the person and the properties of the two minors, Basanta and Ashok.

facts.text: The District Judge, by his order dated June 1, 1953, appointed him temporarily the guardian of the person and properties of Basanta and Ashok, till the disposal of the application, and transferred the file to the Subordinate Judge, L.A.D., Nowgong.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge, by his order dated June 1, 1953, appointed him temporarily the guardian of the person and properties of Basanta and Ashok, till the disposal of the application, and transferred the file to the Subordinate Judge, L.A.D., Nowgong.

facts.text: On December 15, 1953, the Sub-Judge appointed Shri Dwarka Prasad Agarwalla and Shri Nandlal Agarwalla guardians of the person and properties as per the schedule in the application of Basanta and Ashok.

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1953, the Sub-Judge appointed Shri Dwarka Prasad Agarwalla and Shri Nandlal Agarwalla guardians of the person and properties  as per the schedule in the application  of Basanta and Ashok.

facts.text: The guardians were directed to render accounts half yearly in the months of March and September each year, i.e. by the 31st March and 30th September, each year until the minors attained majority.

anchor.surface_text: The guardians were directed to render accounts half yearly in the months of March and September each year, i.e. by the 31st March and 30th September, each year until the minors attained majority.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1954-55, a return was filed in the status of a Joint Hindu Family by the two guardians.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1954-55, which is the subjectmatter of this reference, a return was filed in the status of a Joint Hindu Family by the two guardians.

facts.text: On March 25, 1958, the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, passed an order allowing the guardians to keep and submit separate accounts for each of the minors.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on March 25, 1958, the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, passed the, following order Sup.C.I/66--9 Account upto 30th September, 1957 filed. The guardians file petition seaking permission for showing the accounts of the two minors separately.

facts.text: The Income Tax Officer, by his order dated October 19, 1957, assessed the guardians under s. 23 read with s. 41 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer, by his order dated October 19, 1957, assessed the guardians under s. 23  3  read with s. 41 of the Act.

facts.text: The guardians filed an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner contending that the assessment was bad in law.

anchor.surface_text: The guardians filed an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companytending that the assessment was bad in law.

facts.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner by his order dated May 16, 1956, set aside the assessment and directed the Income Tax-Officer to reassess after obtaining two separate returns.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner by his order dated May 16, 1956, set aside the assessment and directed the Income Tax-Officer to reassess after obtaining two separate returns from the appellants and to frame two separate individual assessments.

facts.text: The Income Tax Officer filed an appeal before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal and the Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and restored the order of the Income Tax Officer with modification that the status is H.U.F.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer filed an appeal before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal and the Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and restored the order of the Income Tax Officer with the modification that the status of the assessee must be described as H.U.F.

facts.text: The guardians put in an application dated December 8, 1958, before the Appellate Tribunal under s. 35.

anchor.surface_text: The guardians put in an application dated December 8, 1958, before the Appellate Tribunal under s. 35 companyplaining that the companytention of the guardians...

facts.text: The Tribunal refused to state a case under s. 66(1) of the Act, but on being directed by the Assam High Court, it drew up a statement of the case and referred the question.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal refused to state a case under s. 66 1  of the Act, but on being directed to do so by the Assam High Court, it drew up a statement of-the case and referred the question set out above.

facts.text: The High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the widow and two minor sons constituted a joint Hindu family and the business was joint family property till partition.

anchor.surface_text: We have already mentioned that Shri Kishanlal was governed by the Mitakshra School of Hindu Law and it appears to us that on his death his widow, and two minor sons, Basanta and Ashok, companystituted a joint Hindu family and the business was joint family property.

facts.text: The appeal is accepted and the question referred to the High Court is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is accepted and the question referred to the High Court is answered in the affirmative.

issues.text: whether in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was justified in assessing the income of the minors in the hands of the guardians as the income of a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The question referred to by the Appellate Tribunal was whether in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was justified in assessing the income of the minors in the hands of the guardians as the income of a Hindu undivided family.

issues.text: whether under the Guardianship Act a guardian could have been appointed in respect of the undivided interest of the minors.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to decide the question whether under the Guardianship Act a guardian could have been appointed in respect of the undivided interest of the minors.

issues.text: the effect of the orders dated June 1, 1953, December 15, 1953 and March 25, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The only question which can be raised is the effect of the orders dated June 1, 1953, December 15, 1953 and March 25, 1958, on which Mr. Sastri strongly relies to establish that the minors had individual incomes.

issues.text: whether the order dated December 15, 1953, of the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, as having effected partition of the property.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot read the order dated December 15, 1953, of the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, as having effected partition of the property.

issues.text: whether S. 40 plainly applies to the facts of this case
whether on his death his widow, and two minor sons, Basanta and Ashok, constituted a joint Hindu family and the business was joint family property.

arguments.claim: Under s. 40 the guardians were liable to pay tax in like manner and to the same amount as it would be leviable upon and recoverable from the minors if of full age, and if the minors had been of full age they would have been assessed as a H.U.F.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General who appears on behalf of the Revenue contends that under s. 40 the guardians were liable to pay tax in like manner and to the same amount as it would be leviable upon and recoverable from the minors if of full age. He says that if the minors had been of full age, they would have been assessed as a H.U.F.

arguments.court_reasoning: S. 40 plainly applies to the facts of this case and consequently the guardians have to be assessed, treating the minors as constituting a H.U.F.

arguments.claim: The minors would not have been assessed as a H.U.F. but would have been assessed individually on their separate incomes.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri, the learned counsel for the respondents, contends that the minors would not have been assessed as a H.U.F. but would have been assessed individually on their separate incomes.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: have already stated, the order dated March 25, 1958, came into existence after the assessment year and after the Income Tax Officer had passed his ord

arguments.court_reasoning: On his death his widow, and two minor sons constituted a joint Hindu family and the business was joint family property.

arguments.claim: Under s. 7 of the Guardians and Wards Act, no guardian could have been appointed in respect of the undivided interest of a minor and therefore the Court must have proceeded on the basis that the properties had been divided among the minors.

anchor.surface_text: He says that under s. 7 of the Guardians and Wards Act, no guardian could have been appointed in respect of the undivided interest of a minor and, therefore, the Court must have proceeded on the basis that the properties had been divided among the minors.

arguments.court_reasoning: It is not necessary to decide the question whether under the Guardianship Act a guardian could have been appointed in respect of the undivided interest of the minors.

arguments.claim: The order dated March 25,1958 shows that the interest of the minors was separate.

anchor.surface_text: He further points to the order dated March 25,1958, which shows that the interest of the minors was separate.

arguments.court_reasoning: The order dated March 25, 1958, came into existence after the assessment year and after the Income Tax Officer had passed his order. It cannot, therefore, have any effect on the position prevailing in the accounting year 1953-54.

arguments.claim: The very fact that separate guardians for the two minors were appointed by the Court with directions to separately account for their accounts and the expenses clearly establishes that they cannot also form a H.U.F.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner by his order dated May 16, 1956, set aside the assessment... He came to the conclusion that the very fact that separate guardians for the two minors were appointed by the Court with directions to separately account for their accounts and the expenses clearly establishes that they cannot also form an U.F.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: and restored the order of the Income Tax Officer with the modification that the status of the assessee must be described as H.U.F. The Appellate Tribu

arguments.court_reasoning: The Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and restored the order of the Income Tax Officer.

arguments.claim: The status of the two minors is only that of H.U.F., as it existed before the curatorship proceedings, and must continue to be so till at least such time that the elder minor attains majority.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer filed an appeal before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal and the Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and restored the order of the Income Tax Officer with the modification that the status of the assessee must be described as H.U.F. The Appellate Tribunal held that the status of the two minors is only that of H.U.F....

arguments.court_reasoning: The appeal is accepted and the question referred to the High Court is answered in the affirmative.

arguments.claim: Under the Hindu Law, by which the minors are governed, their shares are specific and determinate and they can only be assessed under s. 41 in the manner and to the extent the assessment can be made on each of the two minor children individually.

anchor.surface_text: The guardians put in an application dated December 8, 1958... contending that the contention of the guardians that under the Hindu Law, by which the minors are governed, their shares are specific and determinate and they can only be assessed under s. 41...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Law, by which the minors are governed, their shares are specific and determinate and they can only be assessed under s. 41 in the manner an

arguments.court_reasoning: The contention referred to in the application had been omitted to be dealt with in the order of the Tribunal as it became academic in the light of the Tribunals decision that the assessee was a H.U.F.

arguments.claim: The guardians received the shares of these minors in the profit of the business as their income. By the order of the Court, separate accounts... The guardians were thus only liable to pay tax on the amount which they received on behalf of these two minors separately. The guardians will be liable to pay tax on the separate income of each of the minors.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative. The High Court held that the guardians received the shares of these minors in the profit of the business as their income... The guardians will, in our opinion, be liable to pay tax on the separate income of each of the minors.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ult the appeal is accepted and the question referred to the High Court is answer

arguments.court_reasoning: The appeal is accepted and the question referred to the High Court is answered in the affirmative.

arguments.claim: On his death his widow, and two minor sons, Basanta and Ashok, constituted a joint Hindu family and the business was joint family property under Mitakshra School of Hindu Law.

anchor.surface_text: We have already mentioned that Shri Kishanlal was governed by the Mitakshra School of Hindu Law and it appears to us that on his death his widow, and two minor sons, Basanta and Ashok, constituted a joint Hindu family and the business was joint family property.

arguments.claim: Till some positive action was taken to have a partition of the property, it would remain joint family property.

anchor.surface_text: Till some positive action was taken to have a partition of the property, it would remain joint family property.

arguments.claim: The order dated December 15, 1953, of the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, did not effect partition of the property because the Court under the Guardianship Act has no jurisdiction to partition property belonging to a joint Hindu family and there are no words in the order to warrant such a finding.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot read the order dated December 15, 1953, of the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, as having effected partition of the property. Apart from the fact that the Court under the Guardianship Act has no jurisdiction to partition property belonging to a joint Hindu family there are no words in the order to warrant such a finding.

arguments.claim: Agree with the view expressed by Chagla, C.J., in Commissioner of Income Tax Balwantrai Jethalal Vaidya explaining observations in Saifudin Alimohammed v. Commissioner of Income Tax. If a guardian carries on business on behalf of minors and receives income on their behalf, S. 40 of the Act must be applied.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made to Saifudin Alimohammed v. Commissioner of Income Tax and Commissioner of Income Tax Balwantrai Jethalal Vaidya. We agree with the view expressed by Chagla, C.J., in the latter case... If a guardian carries on business on behalf of minors and receives income on their behalf, S. 40 of the Act must be applied.

arguments.claim: S. 40 plainly applies to the facts of this case and consequently the guardians have to be assessed, treating the minors as constituting a H.U.F.
The assessment was bad in law.

anchor.surface_text: The guardians filed an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner contending that the assessment was bad in law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal restored the order of the Income Tax Officer.

holdings.text: on his death his widow, and two minor sons, Basanta and Ashok, constituted a joint Hindu family and the business was joint family property.

anchor.surface_text: constituted a joint Hindu family and the business was joint family property. Till some positive action was taken to have a partition of the property, it would remain joint family property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shri Kishanlal governed by Mitakshra School of Hindu Law; widow and minor sons form joint family post-death.

holdings.text: Till some positive action was taken to have a partition of the property, it would remain joint family property.

anchor.surface_text: Till some positive action was taken to have a partition of the property, it would remain joint family property. We cannot read the order dated December 15, 1953, of the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, as having effected partition of the property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint family property continues unless partitioned by positive action.

holdings.text: the order dated March 25, 1958, came into existence after the assessment year and after the Income Tax Officer had passed his order. It cannot, therefore, have any effect on the position prevailing in the accounting year 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: the order dated March 25, 1958, came into existence after the assessment year and after the Income Tax Officer had passed his order. It cannot, therefore, have any effect on the position prevailing in the accounting year 1953-54.

holdings.text: We cannot read the order dated December 15, 1953, of the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, as having effected partition of the property. Apart from the fact that the Court under the Guardianship Act has no jurisdiction to partition property belonging to a joint Hindu family there are no words in the order to warrant such a finding.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot read the order dated December 15, 1953, of the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, as having effected partition of the property. Apart from the fact that the Court under the Guardianship Act has no jurisdiction to partition property belonging to a joint Hindu family there are no words in the order to warrant such a finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Guardians and Wards Act court lacks jurisdiction to partition HUF property; order lacks words indicating partition.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide the question whether under the Guardianship Act a guardian could have been appointed in respect of the undivided interest of the minors.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to decide the question whether under the Guardianship Act a guardian could have been appointed in respect of the undivided interest of the minors. There is authority for the proposition that when all the coparceners are minors, a guardian can be appointed for the whole estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not raised before tax authorities; parties proceeded on validity of appointment.

holdings.text: the point whether the appointment of guardians was valid or not has not been raised before the Income Tax authorities and we must proceed on the basis that the appointment was valid.

anchor.surface_text: the point whether the appointment of guardians was valid or not has not been raised before the Income Tax authorities and we must proceed on the basis that the appointment was valid. Both the Revenue and the respondents have acted on this assumption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not challenged below; both parties assumed validity.

holdings.text: We agree with the view expressed by Chagla, C.J., in Commissioner of Income Tax Balwantrai Jethalal Vaidya explaining observations in Saifudin Alimohammed v. Commissioner of Income Tax. If a guardian carries on business on behalf of minors and receives income on their behalf, S. 40 of the Act must be applied.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made to Saifudin Alimohammed v. Commissioner of Income Tax and Commissioner of Income Tax Balwantrai Jethalal Vaidya. We agree with the view expressed by Chagla, C.J., in the latter case in which he explained certain observations made in the former case. If a guardian carries on business on behalf of minors and receives income on their behalf, S. 40 of the Act must be applied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows and distinguishes precedents on application of s.40 to guardians of minors carrying on business.

holdings.text: In our opinion S. 40 plainly applies to the facts of this case and consequently the guardians have to be assessed, treating the minors as constituting a H.U.F.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Guardians liable under s.40 as if minors of full age, who would be assessed as HUF.

holdings.text: In the result the appeal is accepted and the question referred to the High Court is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is accepted and the question referred to the High Court is answered in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal justified in assessing guardians as HUF for minors' income.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot read the order dated December 15, 1953, of the Sub-Judge, Nowgong, as having effected partition of the property. Apart from the fact that the Court under the Guardianship Act has no jurisdiction to partition property belonging to a joint Hindu family there are no words in the order to warrant such a finding.
In the result the appeal is accepted and the question referred to the High Court is answered in the affirmative.
